title: Can a LLC in CA successfully dissolve when it has been sued for damages?
question: LLC was sued by two previous employees "labor lawsuit"
question_tags: Employment law for businesses,LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Fraud,Employment,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
The bottom line is that it is unlikely you could avoid paying a lawsuit by dissolving any entity. The liabilities and assets have to be distributed, and assets will be used to satisfy judgments. That will happen because the dissolution and transfer of assets was in fraud of creditors (specially to avoid paying a legitimate claims like lawsuit judgments). Or it could happen because the plaintiffs are able to demonstrate alter ego or some other theory to make owners or former owners personally liable for the claims.

Before you do anything, get legal advice..

What corp? Is it an LLC or what? When you try to dissolve an LLC in CA, you must list all creditors including plaintiffs and payment of the debts must be “adequately provided for.” In the case of a lawsuit, where the amount ultimately to be owed is uncertain, “adequately provided for” generally means that payment has been assumed or guaranteed by a “financially responsible person.” Corp Code Sec17353(c). So you can’t avoid “paying the lawsuit” that way.

Dissolution involves distribution of assets and liabilities. If you distribute the liabilities you could possibly have personal liability where none existed before. Your facts are so vague that the subect is beyond analysis. The smart move would be to have a lawyer review the lawsuit and then give you personalized, specific advice, as opposed to general analysis on a public online forum like Avvo.

It is possible for the LLC to cease operating without having to formally dissolve and wind up. It is also possible for an LLC to dissolve while a lawsuit is pending.

I am not sure what you mean by the LLC is no longer conducting business but the corporation is still open.

Notwithstanding the LLC ceasing to conduct business and/or dissolving, there are various alternative ways an attorney could proceed to impose personal liability on the individuals and/or entities who ought to be liable for the labor claims, including alter ego liability and fraudulent transfer/fraudulent conveyance.
